meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Lilly Settles 18,000 Suits Over Psychiatric Drug Eli Lilly will pay up to $500 million to settle 18,000 lawsuits from people who claimed they developed diabetes or other diseases after taking Zyprexa, its drug for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The agreement brings the total of Zyprexa settlements to at least $1.2 billion, to 28,500 people.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
13 Killed in Baghdad Blasts Two bombs exploded in a Baghdad neighborhood, killing 13 and wounding 22. The toll was just a fraction of the civilians killed in sectarian violence across Iraq this week.
PAGE A10
Vincent Sardi Jr. Is Dead Vincent Sardi Jr., who owned and managed Sardi's restaurant, his father's theater-district landmark and Broadway institution, for more than half a century, is dead at 91.
PAGE B7

In Winter, Some Golf Pros Putt While Others Relax The L.P.G.A. Tour player Christina Kim took a break from most golf drills during the off-season, and while she didn't shun workouts totally, she enjoyed her lavish home in Orlando, Fla.
SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1

Embezzlement Is Found In Catholic Dioceses A survey by researchers at Villanova University found that 85 percent of Roman Catholic dioceses that responded had discovered embezzlement of church money in the last five years, with 11 percent saying more than $500,000 had been stolen. Officials said they were looking for ways to tighten fiscal controls.
PAGE A11
Yankees Trade Johnson The Yankees agreed to send pitcher Randy Johnson back to the Arizona Diamondbacks, almost two years to the day after they acquired him.
SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1
Coming to a Seat Near You Chomping on popcorn at a Broadway show used to be forbidden. Now many theaters are encouraging patrons to grab a drink and a snack and enjoy the show.
WEEKEND, PAGE E1

Lilly Settles 18,000 Suits Over Psychiatric Drug Eli Lilly will pay up to $500 million to settle 18,000 lawsuits from people who claimed they developed diabetes or other diseases after taking Zyprexa, its drug for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The agreement brings the total of Zyprexa settlements to at least $1.2 billion, to 28,500 people.

Officials said they were looking for ways to tighten fiscal controls.
